1.1    Accidental Release Prevention And Response Policies

Redcliff Midstream places the highest priority on the safety of the public, the employees and the environment, and is committed to meeting the most stringent safety standards for assets, operations and personnel. This commitment is demonstrated by the consideration of safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the processes and by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training, written procedures, routine maintenance and inspection programs.



1.2    Description Of The Facility And Regulated Substances

The Redcliff Gas Plant is a 200 MMSCFD cryogenic gas plant. Natural gas enters the plant at 1000 psig and any liquid that condensed in the inlet pipelines, known as condensate, is separated using a Harp-style slug catcher.

Liquid from the Harp is processed in a condensate stabilization unit to produce a stabilized condensate and Y-grade NGL product. Process gas from the Harp is treated to remove hydrogen sulfide (H2S), carbon dioxide (CO2), and water prior to entering the Cryo Plant.

The Cryo Plant is a gas subcooled process (GSP) with refrigeration in which gas is initially cooled using heat integration/recovery from a series of heat exchangers. Use of a turboexpander and reflux exchanger enables the process temperature to be reduced to as low as -150 ?F. A Demethanizer splits the gas into a liquefied Y-Grade NGL product stream containing nearly all ethane and heavier components while simultaneously distilling the product to remove all residual methane which is rejected out of the tower to be sold as sales gas. The NGL stream is pumped to pipeline pressure and marketed to interstate pipelines. The residue gas stream is compressed, filtered, and delivered to transmission lines and sold as sales gas.



The listed flammable substances over the threshold of the 40 CFR Part 68 at the Redcliff Midstream facility are: Butane, Ethane, i-Butane, i-Pentane, Methane, n-Pentane and

Propane.



1.3    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The process at the Redcliff Midstream Plant is subject to both EPA Risk Management Program Rule and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) compliance; therefore, the summary addresses each of the PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the Accident Prevention Program.



1.3.1    Process Safety Information

The Redcliff Midstream facility maintains documents that are used for the safe and reliable operation of facility process. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Responsibility for maintaining process safety information are assigned in order to keep them current and up to date. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). 

Process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, and pressure) have been identified in order to operate the process safely.



Technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment are also maintained. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc.



1.3.2    Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

A formal PHA process is established to help ensure that potential process-related hazards are identified and controlled. PHAs are conducted to identify potential safety and operability hazards associated with the operation and maintenance of the Canyon Midstream Redcliff Plant Project and verify that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. All approved mitigation options in response to PHA findings are implemented and tracked to completion. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained in the facility formal cor

rective action tracking database.



1.3.3    Operating Procedures

Written operating procedures that address the various modes of process operations, to include unit startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process have been developed. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. Formal processes and procedures are developed and maintained to help ensure operating procedures are periodically reviewed and certified annually as current and up-to-date.



1.3.4    Training

A comprehensive training program is maintained for all employees involved in operating a process. Each employee is trained in an overview of the process and in the operating procedures. Special emphasis is given on the specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks.



In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to confirm their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.



1.3.5    Mechanical Integrity

To help ensure covered process equipment is maintained in a safe and reliable condition, procedures and practices are established to include: pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems. The basic aspects of the Mechanical Integrity program include: training, written procedures, inspections and tests, correcting identified deficiencies, and applying quality assurance measures. 



1.3.6    Management of Change

Written procedures are in place to manage changes to the covered process. These procedures require that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, techn

ology (including process operating conditions), and procedures, are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Hazard reviews are conducted to verify adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated as necessary to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.



1.3.7    Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR)

The Redcliff Midstream facility conducts PSSRs when existing facilities/processes are modified and require a change in the process safety information. The intent of the PSSR is to confirm that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications; and that safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.



1.3.8    Compliance Audits.

To determine whether the procedures and practices required by the Accident Prevention Program are being implemented, the Redcliff facility periodically conducts audits, and formal compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years. Findings from the compliance audits are documented in the facility corrective action tracking database and tracked to completion. The two most recent audit reports are retained for review.



1.3.9    Incident Investigation

The Redcliff Midstream facility has established a formal incident reporting and investigation process to promptly investigate all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, chemical release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the root cause of the incident and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops 

corrective action

s to prevent a recurrence.



1.3.10    Employee Participation

Facility management supports and encourages employees to participate in all aspects of risk management and accident prevention. Employee participation range from updating and compiling process safety information to participating as a member of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) team. 



Personnel work together and are involved in areas such as, safety standard and procedures, process safety, hazard evaluation and process safety information update.



1.3.11    Hot Work Permit

The Redcliff Midstream facility issues hot work permit any time work operations are conducted on or near the process in order to verify that fire prevention and protection requirements have been implemented prior to beginning the hot work operations.



1.3.12    Contractors

The Redcliff Midstream facility uses contractors as part of its regular work force and during periods of increased maintenance. Some contractors work on or near process equipment. For this reason the facility has procedures in place to help verify contractors have the appropriate knowledge and skills to perform their work in a safe manner, are aware of the potential hazards in their workplace, understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, understand and follow site safety rules and procedures, and inform plant personnel of any hazards they may discover during the course of their work. 



In addition, contractor safety programs and performance is evaluated as part of the contractor selection process. Plant personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to help ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations. 



1.4    Five Year Accident History

The Redcliff Midstream facility located in Mutual, OK is a new facility and has had no accidental releases to be reported in this section.



1.5    Emergency Response Program

The Redcliff Midstream facility maintains written Emergency Response Procedures and Action Plans to protect worker and p

ublic safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. The Emergency Response Program is periodically reviewed and updated when necessary based on modifications made to plant process.



1.6    Planned changes to improve safety

The Redcliff Midstream  - Mutual, OK facility is a new facility startup. Redcliff Midstream is duly committed to maintaining safety and protecting the environment, and will endeavor to look for safety improvement opportunities whenever possible based on operating experience.
